headline: What happens when a pope dies? Inside the Vatican's historic, symbolic rituals | CBC News
context: Pope Francis, the leader of the Catholic Church since 2013, has died, the Vatican confirmed on Monday.
The 88-year old recently battled double pneumonia and a complex respiratory infection.

annotations.paragraph: The most recent pope to die in office was Pope John Paul II, of heart and kidney failure in 2005. Francis has been leading the church since pope emeritus Benedict XVI resigned in 2013 — the first to do so in more than 600 years.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on recent papal deaths and transitions.

annotations.paragraph: By the time Benedict died in 2022 at age 95, as pope emeritus, some small changes had been made to the funeral mass. We can also expect to see a simpler service for Francis compared to John Paul II's viewings and funeral, which amassed millions of mourners.
annotations.reason: Offers insight into expected changes in the funeral service for Pope Francis.

annotations.paragraph: There are very specific rituals for a papal funeral, explained David Perlich, CBC's Vatican analyst. Historic rituals, some dating back hundreds of years or more, and a series of carefully planned procedures are likely already in motion, he added.
annotations.reason: Introduces the concept of specific rituals and procedures for a papal funeral.

annotations.paragraph: "It's a highly symbolic event, and a highly significant event. It's steeped in centuries of ritual," Perlich said.
annotations.reason: Provides a general statement about the significance of the event without new information.

annotations.paragraph: But before he died, Francis revised some of the funeral rites, simplifying them, so they've taken away some of the more elaborate aspects, Perlich added.
annotations.reason: Details specific changes made by Francis to the funeral rites.

annotations.paragraph: When a pope dies, a series of rites and rituals comes into play governing the "interregnum" — the period between the end of one pontificate and the election of a new pope. During that period, known as the "sede vacante," the camerlengo, or chamberlain, runs the administration and finances of the Holy See.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context about the process following a pope's death.

annotations.paragraph: The camerlengo position is currently held by Cardinal Kevin Farrell, the head of the Vatican's laity office.
annotations.reason: Identifies the current camerlengo, relevant to the process described.

annotations.paragraph: First, the camerlengo will certify the Pope's death.
annotations.reason: Describes the initial step in the process after a pope's death.

annotations.paragraph: In centuries past, tradition held that the camerlengo verified the death by gently tapping the pontiff's head with a silver hammer. This was historically practised while calling out his baptismal name three times, according to the Encyclopedia Britannica, and if he received no response, he would pronounce his death.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on the ritual of verifying a pope's death.

annotations.paragraph: This is a very, very old ritual, done "for a very good reason" to determine whether the pope had actually died, Perlich explained.
annotations.reason: Offers a vague explanation without adding new information.

annotations.paragraph: Today, the Vatican says it's no longer in use, he added. For instance, Pope John Paul II's death in 2005 was confirmed with an ECG.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context on how papal deaths were confirmed, which is relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Receiving no reply, a death certificate is then authorized and the notification process begins. While historically, the pope's death has been announced in St. Peter's square, we can likely expect Francis's death to be announced by the Vatican Press Office. That's what happened when Pope Benedict XVI died in 2022.

annotations.paragraph: Traditionally, bells will toll in St. Peter's square to mark a pope's death. The camerlengo also seals the papal apartments and papers, typically with red ribbons, and ensures the pope's fisherman's ring and the lead seal under which papal documents are dispatched are broken so they cannot be used by anyone else.

annotations.paragraph: Historically, they would smash the ring to destroy it. Now, we're told they score it with a file, Perlich said.

annotations.paragraph: The rituals for the death of a reigning pope include a 30-page constitution called Universi Dominici Gregis, Latin for "The Shepherd of the Lord's Whole Flock," and Ordo Exsequiarum Romani Pontificis, or "Funeral Rites for a Roman Pontiff," a missal of more than 400 pages that includes liturgy, music, and prayers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential context about the documents governing papal death rituals.

annotations.paragraph: Those rules say a pope's burial should take place between four and six days after his death as part of a nine-day period of mourning known as the novendiale.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives specific information about the timeline of the pope's burial and mourning period.

annotations.paragraph: "There's a sorrow that falls on the city that's palpable," Perlich explained.

annotations.paragraph: Behind the scenes, practical matters will be handled, like preparing the Pope's body for public viewing and the procession through St. Peter's square. annotations.paragraph: Historically, a pope's embalmed body has been placed on an elevated bier in St. Peter's Basilica for public viewing. annotations.paragraph: But Francis did away with that tradition when he revised the funeral rites to be used in his death, simplifying the rituals to emphasize his role as a mere bishop. There will only be one vigil over his body instead of two.

annotations.paragraph: And of course, then there's the election of the new pope, called the conclave. At this point, the general mood in Rome shifts from great sorrow to intrigue and speculation, Perlich explained, and the conclave itself proceeds with dignity and subtlety.
